abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Transport Project
            for Brazil were as follows: outcome was satisfactory, risk
            to development outcome was low, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was satisfactory. The
            project design was based on a set of innovative approaches
            and instruments, notably as regards its focus (wide support
            to a client's investment program in road
            rehabilitation), financial management (linking the
            disbursement rate to achievement of sector policy
            indicators), and procurement (opening acceptance, even
            partial, to national procurement rules). A sense of
            "crisis" provide a strong incentive for adopting
            challenging new paradigms but once the crisis subsides,
            clients may rapidly lose interests in advancing such agenda.
            The adoption of the Output Performance Based Road
            Rehabilitation and Maintenance Contract (CREMA) concept is
            the right first step towards an improved road asset
            management in Brazil but a contractual instrument should not
            be considered as a silver bullet to resolve a whole host of
            contract management issues. While the indicators of the
            project result framework need to be selected with great
            caution to ensure that they will appropriately contribute to
            measure project success, innovative approaches may sometimes
            result in unexpected positive outcome. To remain credible
            with sophisticated partners, the Bank may need to deploy
            efforts beyond the extra-mile, which may translate into
            extra resources allocation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Road Transport
            Project is to stimulate higher economic growth by reducing
            road transport costs in the borrower's territory. The
            closing date of the project will be extended by 12 months
            from May 31, 2012 until May 30, 2013. Extension of the
            closing date will enable the achievement of 100 percent of
            the project's physical targets. The extended timeframe
            will also allow completing the key ongoing strategic
            technical assistance activities, which are in various stages
            of execution. This third extension will enable to more fully
            achieve the project's development objective by ensuring
            a continued support for the institutional strengthening
            component of the project. The extended timeframe will also
            allow completing the key ongoing strategic technical
            assistance activities, which are in various stages of
            execution. The current project development objective and
            result indicators continue to be achievable and will be
            enhanced with the extension of the closing date.

display_title.display_title:
Brazil - Road Transport Project :
            restructuring : Main report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Transport Project's
            ultimate development objective is to stimulate higher
            economic growth by increasing effectiveness in the use of
            the federal road infrastructure. The objective is to be
            achieved through: support to the first phase of the federal
            road maintenance and rehabilitation program, and a
            comprehensive program of institutional strengthening
            activities to improve efficiency and sustainability of road
            transport investment programs. The changes consist of: a)
            two minor alterations to clarify the type of interventions
            under the investment component and widen the scope of one
            subcomponent of the technical assistance component, b) a
            reallocation and a partial cancellation of the loan
            proceeds, and c) an 11-month extension of the closing date
            of the loan (a second extension, for a cumulative total
            extension of 23 months) to May 31, 2012 from the current
            closing date June 30, 2011.

display_title.display_title:
Brazil - Road Transport Project :
            restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
